really briefly let me touch on what does this mean what does this move from the statistical approaches to neural

algorithm it takes parallel corpora so a bunch of text in one language bunch of
text in the other language which is parallel basic a direct translation one of the other and learns to perform a
lookup between these two texts so basically when it starts translating it says hey I have this word or let's say
two to three words what is the what is the combination of words in the target
language that has the highest probability to be the translation of the words that I'm working on right now now
this has made a lot of content available for us that we couldn't have made available in other languages otherwise
but the problem and the challenge and the sort of limitation for us to take it
and and and and use it across the board for every use case that we want to use machine translation for has been the
fact that these engines don't have a notion of understanding the meaning there's no notion of creating a semantic
representation of text that was in the statistical approach with their neural networks this is a totally different
approach what we're doing with the neural networks is basically imitating the way that the human brain learns and
then processes information after its learned what to do with the specific information and this means that they
have been trained to create a semantic representation of the source content that they're working on to translate
that means that they understand the context of the sentence that they you know they translate the full sentence

I had two questions one was have you have you guys figured out a metric for
quality of translation in AWS translate I mean you kind of highlighted it on the screen but to be able to do an
apples-to-apples comparison and then the second question was just about pricing you didn't touch on that at all yeah
great questions so with regard to quality first of all there's two
approaches for doing that one is a sort of a quantitative approach so there's a bunch of algorithms that do that for you
so you take a reference translation done by a human linguist and you compare the output that you've produced with your
engine to that translation that produces a score there's multiple approaches to
this the scientific community is super excited about you know developing new and and constantly improving algorithms
some of them are blue media or tear h slap or really there's a bunch of
approaches to how you might do that the second approach which we normally do when we're about to release a new round
of models is using human evaluators so we basically take a set of several
hundreds of sentences which we create from multiple domains it's twelve domains less I checked because we're
trying to basically cover any kind of content that customers might use the service for and we run a human
evaluation so we take several human linguists that this is you know their profession is to translate text like
these and we have them rate basically to a double-blind evaluation have them rate
our translation and a linguist produce translation to to the same source text
and then we basically look what is the what is the Delta between the two to decide hey is this is because is this
good enough as our next iteration or do we need to do some more stuff the
quantitative approaches I'd say are very widely used because doing these human
evaluation costs a lot not everyone can afford themselves to do several hundreds
of sentences of evaluations every time they released a new feature but you know
